title: Nvidia, AMD to Pay 15% on China AI Chip Sales to US Government
description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests: StoneX Financial Chief Market Strategist Kathryn Rooney Vera, Bloomberg's Caroline Hyde and Kate Sullivan.  (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: The article discusses the news of AMD and NVIDIA agreeing to pay 15% of their REVENUE to the US Government in exchange for exporting AI chips from China. The companies will pay $7.7 billion in return for these chips. The article also discusses the potential for the International Association of Industry Co-operation (IMitability) to be a benchmark in the global economy. Meanwhile, there are concerns about the potential impact of the looming inflation of the US economy and potential for a stagnating economy. The IMF has also increased its U.S. GDP REvisations, and the S & P 500 could close at a record high if the S&P 500 closes at these levels, which would mark a record low for the year.
shortSummary: Nvidia and AMD will pay 15% of their revenue from China AI chip exports to the US government, amid volatile markets amid rising inflation concerns and political tensions.
argos_summary: The article discusses the current state of the markets, focusing on upcoming inflation reports and the performance of semiconductor stocks, particularly Intel, AMD, and NVIDIA, who have agreed to pay a percentage of their revenues to the U.S. government. It also highlights the mixed performance of biotech and cannabis stocks, the implications of potential stagflation, and the impact of geopolitical events on emerging markets like Colombia. Additionally, President Trump has announced federal control over Washington D.C.'s police department in response to crime concerns, despite data indicating a decrease in violent crime.
